Pay and benefit are good
Lots of social causes, even if they are often corporate green washing
cons:
Promotion process is notoriously unfair. Assumed that all will fail in the first year.
Reputation of bank is rightly very poor because of past behaviour.
Constant strategy changes over the past few years are still being cleaned up, meaning estate is still a bit of a mess.
Massive over reliance on consultancy firms. Its a running joke that MDs will get Accenture or Mackenzie in to do an assessment for €Ms which will be full of flashy slides with no substance, and then some poor VP will get lumbered with delivering something which is very poorly defined.
Strategy is very much away from hubs. Anybody in UK, US or SG will likely be told that their job needs constant justification for them not to be replaced in non hub location. DE resources are protected from this because of good labour laws and union.

review_title: Treausury is great, though a slow and steady environment...
job_title: Vice President Treasury in London, England
pros:
DB is significantly into executing a strategic overhaul, which is going better than the Street ever expected. Treasury contributed toward this initiative significantly and this is acknowledged across the firm

Treasury has some incredibly smart people who you can learn from

For a department that is traditionally very technical (capital, liquidity, issuance, irbb etc), there is significant focus on soft skills, which is extremely helpful for personal development and enhances saleability when looking for future jobs

It is possible to have a great work life balance. Treasury provides a job for life if so you desire, slow and steady, especially in Frankfurt and more recently London. This comes with its own disadvantages though. Its up to you to push yourself

If joining from externally and you negotiate, salary can be excellent. Benefits are also excellent. Bonuses are OK. Total packages are strong
cons:
Technical excellence seems to be valued below soft skills in the internal value hierarchy. This leads to poor outcomes for a department which by its nature deals in technical topics. 

Part of DB's overhaul includes cost cutting. This has been felt negatively in Treasury and Finance in multiple ways. 

Career progression is possible in the long term but happens at a snails pace for anything other than the more junior levels due to cost pressure. You may find this frustrating, unless you are happy with slow and steady. 

The firm is extremely bureaucratic and slow in some areas. It can be difficult to get things done. Cost pressures mean areas like technology suffer, making it even more difficult to get things done.

Salary rises occur by exceedingly rare exception, mainly for juniors. Salary freezes are frequent for multiple years, even for top performers. Make sure you negotiate the best possible starting salary!

Like many large firms, DB, and TSY in particular, is very far from a meritocracy. Its possible to tick along and receive no medium term outlook difference in ratings appraisals etc against those who strive for excellence. High ratings are also a function of time in the firm in many cases. 

Due to cost pressures, hiring freezes are common. External hires have not been possible in many instances, meaning roles must be filled internally. This can cause issues in deeply technical areas, a brain drain has occurred in Treasury over the past year or two.

review_title: Don't waste your career in this place
pros:
Good office environment
Free coffee and tea
cons:
Bureaucracy
No RAISE in 3 years! Keep trending in this company. They don't want to keep up with inflation. People are loosing money every year while working here
A lot of turnaround - good talents are leaving every time
Top management only want to implement systems that are on top of other systems to justify their high paycheck
For promotions they have a mystery Panel (nobody knows who they are and/or which departments they work for).
For promotions the best way is to leave and come back in a few months applying for a higher role, otherwise it takes a few years.
Terrible bonus ! its always a percentage of the percentage.... Let's say the bonus is 4% of your salary, at the end of the year the higher I've seen is the 50% of the 4%. Literally a 2% bonus.
During the pandemic the company provided zero support for their employees. They saved money by not having anyone going into the office and they could no provide help to set up their workers at home.
On month three or four after the pandemic started they wanted people to come to the office. The operations manger is clueless of what a pandemic is.
Fixing issues depends on a lot of people where 50% of them will care, the other 50% will ignore all your requests bc its not part of their role.

pros: To be clear, the people I worked with at Deutsche Bank (and having a job during a global pandemic) are the primary reasons I stayed at this company for 2.5 years. My direct team, manager, and stakeholders I worked with have been some of the most supportive people I have encountered in my careers and it’s a shame the company treats everyone so poorly. The benefits however, are great. Depending on title, you can start off with 20 vacation days which is a lot for US employees. There are fertility benefits for women that provide generous financial support in IVF, surrogacy, and freezing eggs with is huge!
cons: To be clear, this review is about Deutsche Bank as a whole - not my team, or any of the people I directly worked with. Where do I even begin - internally the company is a mess beginning from the onboarding phase. Why do you need documentation of all my prior jobs and copies of my degrees if you are running a background check against my resume anyways? Not a great start. For an investment bank that has been touting all its success on various platforms DB is shamelessly cheap. During the pandemic, HR (and junior bankers) were given no support for our work from home setups. I was forced to use my personal laptop (which by the way was 6 years old), purchase my own desk, monitors, keyboard, and mouse. When I asked for reimbursement I was told by senior management VERBATIM “you work at an investment bank, you can afford it” (I was certainly not making investment banker salary in HR). Then 6 months in they allowed HR employees to come into the office and take our monitors, chairs, etc. ONLY because they were mothballing the floor in anticipation of the office move - such a hollow effort because 1. Everything was going to be trashed anyways and 2. We all had our setups at that point. There was a lot of turnover on my team because the workload was unrealistic especially since we were always short staffed. We had a lot of turnover in 2019 after the restructuring announcement then a hiring freeze so my team was incredibly under resourced for a full year. We were not given additional compensation for going above and beyond, just a simple pat on the back. Another point on the the restructuring process and “location strategy” - nothing like signing into work everyday during a pandemic and hoping its not the day you are restructured or your position is moved to Jacksonville because it’s a cheaper labor market. When I resigned, there had been a series of resignations from my team in close proximity to eachother. I asked for a counteroffer and DB did nothing to even attempt to retain me therefore making my former team suffer from the continual cycle of being understaffed. This company doesn’t care about its employees, it cares about the bottom line. Working for my new company is like realizing that you were previously and unknowingly in an abusive relationship.

- Great colleagues with a very international, collaborative approach to working. 
- Very interesting projects with plenty of opportunity to work on complex problems, at scale, globally.
- Making some good progress to finally deliver on the strategy, but lots of pain along the way for employees due to cost cutting
- Great internal opportunities and plenty of scope to create your own career path
cons:
- A brand that had been tarnished by years of misbehavior by a very small number of people.
- Extreme focus on cost cutting led by teams that did not have the expertise or insight to balance short term savings against longer term risks
- Decisions increasingly made from Frankfurt HQ by people that did not understand the complexity - or in some cases the simplicity - of international operations

review_title: Only apply if you enjoy being a perpetual temp with no benefits
job_title: Document Reviewer in Santa Ana, CA
pros: None that I could think of.
cons:
The "temps" here work for years for this company. Some people go years without having raises  or raises so minuscule one wonders if it was a joke .  A lot of them make ends meet by doing copious amounts of overtime. Since DB is the biggest customer of these temp agencies, be prepared for them to drop you should you complain about DB's horrid work environment. Management is clueless at best and malicious at worst. There is this one manager that not only treats the deaf employees badly, but she makes it her mission to go to different departments NOT under her supervision just so she can get her kicks from having people fired. Many employees have complained about her but nothing is done since she's a permanent employee of DB and the people complaining are temps. As for other managers, they promote the laziest and biggest brown-nosers imaginable to lead positions and then wonder why work isn't get done. Instead they blame the grunts who are actually doing the work for the screwups. The volume of work is increasing daily but instead of hiring more, they just expect everybody to work weekends. Unsurprisingly, the turnover is high all around.

This company just fired a hundred people because they outsourced most of the processing to a different country.  All those temp agencies bending over backwards was for naught.  Expect neither loyalty, fairness or even competency from Deutsche Bank.

review_title: No Leadership, No Training, No Help
job_title: Production Support Engineer in Cary, NC
pros: Job is obtainable at a decent salary even if you aren't qualified.
cons:
Many of us were lied to about what the job was when we were hired. The original job posting was for an Automation Engineer. They put us in IT Support. This caused so many people to quit that all the teams are short staffed and overworked. Now that the old site manager is gone and a new one is hiring with honest postings, no one actually wants the job. Probably why they lied in the first place.
Management is a joke, there's no plan, no training, no one helps each other, especially between regions. It's basically the uppers complaining about things until someone hopefully fixes it. They roll over when other teams push back, which means there's no consistency in how to operate, and no documentation to refer to how it's actually supposed to run.
Everyone is so swamped with work that there's no time to do the 'Automation' job that we were supposedly being hired to do. It's just user support issues. They took away the level 1 support so now both jobs fall on the production teams. Tasks that should be handled by the devs are also on the production team, again because the leadership just rolls over and doesn't stand up for their team.
On the occasion someone manages to get on a call with the uppers to raise concerns. Their solution is to stop having those calls with the teams. Mention this to the site managers and they laugh and do nothing about it. And they wonder out loud (again complaining instead of planning) why everyone is quitting.
No one is willing to help each other. There's no training. There's nothing to learn. The things you waste your afternoon talking about that's supposed to be 'training' never get used.
There's no documentation, not even for the users, who come to you constantly for advice on how to use a program you didn't make. You get yelled at for not resolving issues that you can't fix. You get yelled at for doing something that you thought was policy because someone complained so that's not policy anymore. You're constantly on the hook for another teams work that you're waiting on, and there's no accountability if they don't fix the issue because again, leadership just rolls over.
The people you work with a nice enough, because we're all in it together, but I don't know a single person there that's happy to work at Deutsche Bank.
